title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: We first investigated molecular changes in neurons that occur during aging in the hippocampus
context: —a brain region regulating learning and memory and highly vulnerable to the effects of aging11,13—

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: Transcriptomic analysis detected 28 genes with increased expression and 81 genes with decreased expression with age (Fig. 1e and Supplementary Table 1)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: Gene Ontology analysis of differentially expressed genes predominantly identified synapse-related processes, such as regulation of synapse structure or activity and regulation of synapse assembly (Fig. 1b)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: To gain insight into age-related molecular changes at the synaptic level
outcome: we performed comparative proteomics analysis of the synaptic fraction (synaptosome) in both young and aged mouse brains using isobaric tagging coupled with mass spectrometry (Fig. 1c)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: Proteomic analysis detected 27 proteins with increased abundance and 19 proteins with decreased abundance in aging (Fig. 1e and Supplementary Table 2)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: Gene Ontology analysis highlighted biological processes related to immune responses and complement activation
context: which are known to be associated with synaptic remodeling in neurons16

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: Comparison of our neuronal transcriptomic and synaptic proteomic datasets identified one factor with conserved increased expression: the iron-associated protein ferritin light chain 1 (FTL1)17–19 (Fig. 1e–g and Extended Data Fig. 1a)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: To investigate the relationship between increased FTL1 and cognition
outcome: we correlated hippocampal FTL1 expression with cognitive performance on a battery of hippocampal-dependent learning and memory tasks in an independent cohort of young and aged mice

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Identification of Neuronal FTL1 as an Age-Related Factor
main_content: We observed a significant negative association between increased hippocampal FTL1 expression by western blot and impaired overall cognitive performance (Fig. 1g,h and Supplementary Table 3)
outcome: These data identify FTL1 as a potential pro-aging neuronal factor with implications for cognitive dysfunction

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vitro
main_content: To assess the effect of mimicking an age-related increase in neuronal FTL1
outcome: we used a cell-type-specific, viral-mediated overexpression approach

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vitro
main_content: detected a decrease in the total neurite length and dendritic complexity of MAP2+ neurons overexpressing FTL1 compared to control (Fig. 2a)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vitro
main_content: No differences in neuronal cell density or toxicity were observed under FTL1 overexpression conditions (Extended Data Fig. 2d,e)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: we investigated the effect of increasing neuronal FTL1 in the adult hippocampus
context: Having observed neuronal changes in vitro
outcome: Young mice were given bilateral stereotaxic injections of high-titer lentivirus encoding Ftl1 or GFP under the control of the neuron-specific synapsin-1 promoter into the CA1 and dentate gyrus regions of the hippocampus (Fig. 2b and Extended Data Fig. 3a,b)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: To begin, we characterized changes in redox states of free iron (Fe) after increased neuronal FTL1 in the hippocampus
outcome: using DNAzyme-based fluorescent turn-on sensors that are selective for either ferrous (Fe2+) or ferric (Fe3+) states20

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: Fe2+ and Fe3+ were detected simultaneously in the hippocampus, and an increase in Fe3+ was observed in neurons overexpressing FTL1 (Fig. 2c)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: To further understand changes in iron redox cycling
outcome: we compared the relative Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: observed a concomitant increase after neuronal FTL1 overexpression (Fig. 2c)
outcome: These data suggest that increased FTL1 promotes accumulation of oxidized iron in hippocampal neurons

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: To examine aging-associated synaptic alterations14
outcome: we assessed presynaptic and postsynaptic molecular markers after increased neuronal FTL1 in the hippocampus

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: detected a decrease in PSD95+ excitatory and gephyrin+ inhibitory synapses in the hippocampus of mice overexpressing neuronal FTL1 compared to control (Fig. 2d,e)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: Additionally, we observed reduced expression of glutamate NMDA receptor subunit 2A (NR2A), AMPA receptor and synapsin by western blot (Extended Data Fig. 3c)
context: consistent with previously described age-related changes associated with impairments in synaptic plasticity14
outcome: Our data suggest that increasing neuronal FTL1 promotes aging-associated synaptic changes in the adult hippocampus

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: To investigate the functional impact of increasing neuronal FTL1 in the hippocampus
outcome: we assessed long-term potentiation (LTP) and cognition in young mice after viral-mediated neuronal FTL1 overexpression (Fig. 2f–i)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: observed lower LTP levels from the CA1 of young animals overexpressing neuronal FTL1 compared to control conditions (Fig. 2f)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: young mice with increased expression of neuronal FTL1 were cognitively impaired, demonstrating no preference (Fig. 2h,i)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Mimicking Age-Related FTL1 Increases In Vivo (Young Mice)
main_content: As a control, we profiled general health using an open-field paradigm and observed no differences in overall activity, total distance traveled or time spent in the center of the open field, indicative of normal motor and anxiety functions (Extended Data Fig. 3d–f)
outcome: Our functional data indicate that mimicking an age-related increase in neuronal FTL1 negatively regulates synaptic plasticity and hippocampal-dependent memory

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Abrogating Neuronal Ftl1 In Vitro
main_content: To begin to investigate the converse effect of abrogating neuronal Ftl1
outcome: we used a complementary viral-mediated RNA interference in vitro approach

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Abrogating Neuronal Ftl1 In Vitro
main_content: Decreased neuronal FTL1 expression (Extended Data Fig. 4c) resulted in an increase in total neurite length as well as in dendritic complexity of MAP2+ neurons by immunocytochemical analysis (Fig. 3a)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Abrogating Neuronal Ftl1 In Vitro
main_content: No differences in neuronal cell density or toxicity were observed under RNA interference conditions (Extended Data Fig. 4d,e)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: to explore the potential benefit of targeting the age-related increase of FTL1 in the hippocampus of aged mice
outcome: We performed targeted stereotaxic injections of a high-titer virus encoding shRNA sequences targeting either Ftl1 or luciferase control into the CA1 and dentate gyrus hippocampal regions of aged mice (Fig. 3b and Extended Data Fig. 5a,b)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: targeting Ftl1 led to an increase in PSD95+ excitatory and gephyrin+ inhibitory synapses in the aged hippocampus (Fig. 3c,d)
context: in contrast to the effects observed with FTL1 overexpression

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: Additionally, we observed an increase in NR2A, AMPA receptor and synapsin by western blot (Extended Data Fig. 5c)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: Consistent with age-related cognitive decline, control aged mice showed no preference for either a novel object or a novel arm relative to a familiar condition (Fig. 3f,g)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: Notably, abrogating FTL1 in the aged hippocampus resulted in cognitive improvements (Fig. 3f,g)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: No differences in overall activity were detected between experimental groups (Extended Data Fig. 5d–f)
outcome: These data suggest that targeting hippocampal FTL1 restores known age-related synaptic molecular changes and cognitive function in aged mice

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: To determine the effect of selectively targeting the age-related increase in neuronal FTL1
outcome: we generated aged, temporally controlled, neuron-specific conditional Ftl1 genetic knockout mice (FTL1 cKO) using a viral-mediated in vivo CRISPR–Cas9 approach

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: We observed an increase in PSD95+ excitatory and gephyrin+ inhibitory synapses by immunocytochemical analysis and an increase in NR2A, AMPA receptor and synapsin by western blot in the hippocampus of aged FTL1 cKO mice compared to controls (Fig. 3i,j and Extended Data Fig. 6c)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: Consistent with abrogation of hippocampal FTL1, selectively targeting neuronal Ftl1 resulted in cognitive improvements in memory in FTL1 cKO mice compared to control mice (Fig. 3l,m)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Targeting FTL1 in the Aged Hippocampus
main_content: No differences in overall activity were detected between experimental groups (Extended Data Fig. 6d–f)
outcome: These behavioral data indicate that targeting neuronal FTL1 at old age mitigates age-related cognitive impairments

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: To identify potential mechanisms underlying the pro-aging effects of increased neuronal FTL1 on cognitive function
outcome: we characterized the transcriptomes of hippocampal neurons from young and aged mice after viral-mediated FTL1 overexpression and abrogation, respectively, by neuronal nuclei RNA-seq approaches (Fig. 4a,d)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: We detected 100 differentially expressed genes in young mice overexpressing neuronal FTL1 and 309 differentially expressed genes in aged mice after hippocampal FTL1 knockdown compared to control conditions (Fig. 4b,e and Supplementary Tables 4 and 5)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: We performed Gene Ontology analysis and identified changes in energy metabolism pathways and synaptic processes (Fig. 4c,f)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: To gain further regional and cell-type-specific resolution
outcome: we assessed molecular changes elicited by viral-mediated Ftl1 knockout by single-nuclei RNA-seq (Fig. 4g)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: Gene Ontology analysis of differentially expressed genes between FTL1 cKO and control mice identified predominantly metabolic processes (Fig. 4i)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: Concordantly, we observed increased expression of genes related to aerobic respiration and proton-driven ATP synthesis in excitatory neurons of FTL1 cKO mice (Extended Data Fig. 8a–d)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: Gene Ontology analysis of differentially expressed genes identified metabolic processes associated with ATP production, oxidative phosphorylation and NADH across hippocampal neuronal cell types (Fig. 4j–l)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: (missing)
outcome: we next surveyed our in vivo neuronal FTL1 overexpression RNA-seq (Fig. 4a), in vivo neuronal Ftl1 RNA interference RNA-seq (Fig. 4d) and in vivo Ftl1 cKO single-nuclei RNA-seq (Fig. 4g) datasets for convergent molecular pathways

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: Of the genes that are downregulated in the young hippocampus after increased neuronal FTL1 and upregulated in the aged hippocampus after abrogation of neuronal FTL1, we detected 32 genes that were bidirectionally changed (Fig. 4m and Supplementary Table 6)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: Gene Ontology analysis of this gene set identified metabolic processes associated with ATP production and oxidative phosphorylation (Fig. 4n), with restored neuronal expression of genes including Sdhb, Atp5o, Atp5c1, Ndufa10 and Atp5j in the aged hippocampus after abrogation of neuronal FTL1 (Fig. 4o)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: To corroborate our RNA-seq findings using an orthogonal approach
outcome: we measured neuronal ATP production rate by Seahorse assay after viral-mediated overexpression and abrogation of FTL1 in primary neurons

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: Increasing neuronal FTL1 significantly compromised ATP production (Fig. 4p), whereas abrogation of FTL1 resulted in increased ATP production compared to control conditions (Fig. 4q)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: To begin to test this possibility
context: Consequently, we reasoned that boosting metabolic function might counter the pro-aging effects of increased neuronal FTL1
outcome: primary neurons were treated with NADH (a coenzyme driving ATP synthesis during oxidative phosphorylation)21–23 after viral-mediated FTL1 overexpression (Fig. 4r and Extended Data Fig. 9a)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: Consistent with our previous observation, we detected a decrease in the total neurite length and dendritic complexity of MAP2+ neurons overexpressing FTL1 compared to control (Fig. 4r); however, this decrease was mitigated after NADH treatment (Fig. 4r)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: To investigate the effect of NADH supplementation on cognitive function
outcome: young adult mice were administered NADH after viral-mediated neuronal FTL1 overexpression, and hippocampal-dependent memory was assessed by NOR and Y maze (Fig. 4s)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: Although young mice with increased neuronal FTL1 expression showed no preference for either a novel object or a novel arm, these cognitive deficits were mitigated after NADH supplementation (Fig. 4t,u)

title: Targeting iron-associated protein Ftl1 in the brain of old mice improves age-related cognitive impairment
subsection: Transcriptomic and Metabolic Mechanisms
main_content: No differences in overall activity were detected between experimental groups (Extended Data Fig. 10a–d)
outcome: These transcriptomics and behavioral data indicate that the pro-aging effects of increased neuronal FTL1 on cognitive function are mediated, at least in part, through alterations in metabolic processes
